description.text:
J1772 connector hanger with hood and cable mount hood.
Based on erroneus's design but with thicker support structure and no inner connection ports. 30 degree hanger. Also reduced the overhang of the final lip to only be 45 degrees off base. Not over 45 degrees.
Printed it. It's working great. I might bevel out the inside to make the plug slide in more fluidly. I'll probably try this with a dremel first. This is not a tight fit, but that's okay, the push button latch does the job of holding plug in place.
The lip is working to hold cable on. I think it might work a bit better if I reduced the downward angle leading to the lip on the hood. The cable hasn't fallen yet, but it feels like in heavy winds it might. There's lots of free space inside of the housing. I might* Remove some of that free space and reduce this downward angle at the same time. *I have removed this space and uploaded an updated version called j1772hanger_smaller. It has the same wall footprint, so your existing screw holes can be reused. I have also added the requested air hole. The smaller hanger bracket only has a clearance of 24 millimeters between the inside of the plug house and the underside of the underside of the cord hanger. Please measure your plug to make sure it will fit.

You may wish to add a skirt to prevent warping. You know your printer better than I do.

description.text:
After a couple failed attempts to print parts the are supposed to be mated together (they didn't fit), I realized that I don't fully understand how much error my printer has in each axis. So I designed these cubes which can be used to come up with an error profile for your printer. For each print setting you want to test (speed, number of shells, layer height, etc), print this out, and use a caliper to take 5 measurements on each of the 3 pieces and compare to the expected sizes. Measure: X-inner (hole) width
X-outer (peg) width
Y-inner (hole) width
Y-outer (peg) width
Z height I expect that if you tell the printer to print a cube with X-axis size S, the actual printed size, T, will have both constant error, c (like 0.28 mm), and multiplicative error, m (like 4.6%). In otherwords: T = m*S + c Therefore, you technically only need two pieces to get two (S,T) pairs you can plug in and solve for m and c. I print three, because I want to do the calculation between each pair and confirm the answers match (approximately) Notes:
-- The X and Y dimensions of the cube are the same size, but only X is marked in the diagrams.
-- My printer does have different errors in X and Y, so be sure to measure and compute them separately
-- The notches in the upper-right corner are simply to maintain XY-orientation after you've removed them from the build platform. Without it, you may not remember which direction was X and which was Y.
-- Technically, you could probably figure out inner sizes just from the outer sizes, but I wanted more-direct measurements, since part of the reason I'm doing this is so I can make pegs and slots that fit on the first try.
-- I purchased this caliper on Amazon and love it. Totally worth $30 (and appears to be fairly accurate despite the price) TODO: Will make a simple python script that will let you type in your measurements, and will estimate "m" and "c" for you. Then, let you type in the target size of an object, and it will tell you how big to model it (or scale it, if already made), to get the target size.

comments.text: In case anyone ends up here by looking at some of my SolidPython scripts that "import caldata", below is what my caldata.py file looks like based on the measurements in my example (the comment before this one).  In my SolidPython scripts, whenever I create a peg, I use (xSize + xoAdj - margin) in the x-dim and (ySize + yoAdj - margin) in the y-dim.  Use (xsz + xiAdj + margin) and (ysz + yiAdj + margin) if creating a slot.    If it's a circular peg or slot, I just use the avg (xiAdj+yiAdj)/2 or (xoAdj+yoAdj)/2.   I usually set "margin" to 0.5 (mm)

description.text:
Update July 23, 2012:
Uploaded a more stable version 3 of the fan mounts that are solid between the two screw mounts for the fan. Update May 21, 2012:
I don't know why I didn't think of this in the first place, but I've made a version 2 of the previous mounts that print flat on their backs instead of standing up. This gives them a more solid structural support and will hopefully keep them from breaking easily. Update May 16, 2012:
I've also uploaded a 20 and a 30 degree angled version (named with the postfix 20d and 30d) of the mount in case you want your fans to aim downward. This is a 40mm fan mount meant to be mounted on the bolt(s) that connect the extruder block to the X-Carriage on the MakerGear Prusa and is meant to be inline with the X tracks.

It is a rather delicate and small part, so be careful when printing.  You can print just one to use with a single fan, but my purposes for this was to have an even distribution of fan on either side.
I've included an image to better show how this thing is mounted onto the X-Carriage.

comments.text: A small chamfer on the interior of the L bracket to make that part a little stronger would be nice - I just broke two of them today, and they held together except on the inside of the L.  Now, it would have broken just about anything (don't ask...) but it still pointed out that it's a significant wear point.  Shouldn't affect the operation/mounting, only increase strength.  I'd make the derivative but it's such a small change I thought I'd just mention it and see if you wanted to incorporate it into yours.
comments.author: fehknt

comments.text: The little lip on the version 1 STL file made me install it upside down and the fan was too low. (I though the lip was to catch on the x- carriage to keep it from rotating, instead of being where the washer/nut hit.) I printed the V3 one before I figured it out and the V3 one definitely keeps the bottom of the fan above the nozzle level.  So, N.B. the small tab that connects to the fan goes UP, not down.
comments.author: summetj

comments.text: Ah yes, I tried to include a diagram image of how it fits onto the carriage, but I'm sorry if it was unclear.
comments.author: summetj

comments.text: No problems, I figured it out. Another N.B......print them in ABS, not in PLA....I had one working fine while I was printing PLA with my heated bed at 60c, but then I changed back to ABS and cranked up the heat bed to 110c and one time when I left the extruder/fan/x-carrage over the heat bed while it was heating up the PLA softened and the fan slowly fell down into the print....so I used it as an excuse to print 2 in ABS and mount a 2nd fan on the other side...
comments.author: Lochemage

comments.text: After staring at this for awhile, I realized it wont work for the new MG Prusa.
comments.author: Roach

comments.text: I'm not sure how the belt pullies have changed exactly on the new prusa, but the ones I'm using in those pictures aren't the original ones either, I changed to gt2.  Before you write it off, I would at least upgrade the prusa first and then see if you can't adjust the pullies to fit.  The pully mount is adjustable.
comments.author: Roach

comments.text: Great fan mount! I have one request, could you possibly update the mount to have a solid piece between the two mounts for the fan? I can't see anything on my Prusa that would require the space and having them connected would make it much stronger.
comments.author: Renae

comments.text: Thanks for your input!  I have uploaded a version 3 of the fan mounts that are solid between the two screw holes, is this what you were asking for?
comments.author: Renae

comments.text: Awesome response time! That is exactly what I asked for, thanks! However... Another day, two more thoughts... I'm not yet up to deriving things so I have (I believe) one last modification request. Can you raise the fan 5mm... Hold on, looks like you already did. Is that true? Secondly, since the top half of the fan is blocked, can you make a channel that directs the flow down using the space between the X-carriage plastic? I've made a drawing...
comments.author: Lochemage

comments.text: Well, the mount already raises the fan a bit, are you asking that it be raised higher?  Just keep in mind that the top part of the fan gets blocked, so raising it will only increase the area that is blocked.
comments.author: Renae

comments.text: I'm pretty sure (not printed yet) based on your pictures that the fan mounting holes have been raised on V3 compared to V2. I'm not sure by how much based on the picture but it looks just about perfect. This leaves the second request. I'll derive your thing if it's still something I need/want when I learn how to model.

comments.text: Yeah, it was actually an earlier change that I didn't post.  I increased the height a little bit on the 90 degree mount for clearance issues on my own printer.  Sorry, I forgot I did that.

title: Exhaust Header Pie Cut 1.5" dia 3" CLR 9 degree cuts

description.text:
This is a mock up exhaust pie cut, with a 1.5" diameter, a 3" CLR (center line radius) and 9 degree cuts on either end. They snap together, and can rotate as needed. They're marked along the circumference to make it easier to clock sections that are rotated against each other. 10 pieces makes a 90' bend.

It's made as a straight section of tube; there's no curve to the model itself. This mimics what you'd get if you were cutting your own pie cut sections from 1.5" straight metal tube, rather than using mandrel bends. I'll add some straight sections soon.

title: Travel Pill Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Never know when you'll need a pain reliever, tum, or what have you. Sometimes it is inconvenient to keep a whole bottle on your person when you will most likely only need two tablets of whatever at the time. That's why I made this container, it is minimalistic and is a must have on your desk at work. These antacids are not name brand and are a bit smaller than normal ones (I think, I don't have any actual TUMs to compare). These are from a brand called "equate", and are easily found at Walmart. Everything else is pretty standard though.

I will be looking to remake this in the near future with a hinge so that the lid does not slide off. This would make is so you don't have to be so careful putting it in your pocket.

Homebrew Monstrosity

Notes:

If tolerances are tight, just print both the lid and holder at a slightly larger size (e.g. 101%). Those who have printers with high accuracy should have no issue.

Attaching the Magnets

This is intended to be used with small 3mm diameter x 1.5mm deep neodymium magnets, which can be purchased cheap just about anywhere. Just use some super glue to hold 'em in place.
I got mine here, which are uncommon on their website because it is a bulk surplus purchase, and they usually have imperial measurements only.
http://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=ZD4
1/8" x 1/16" is the closest imperial equivalent and should also work, may be a bit of a tighter squeeze but the tolerance of the hole diameter should still be good enough for that. So for anyone looking to make a smaller and cheaper order with imperial magnets, try this link
http://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=D21

title: Delft DU84-132V3 Airfoil Micro Drone Propeller (41.09g thrust @ 3V)

description.text:
This drone propeller has been designed using the Delft DU84-132V3 airfoil coordinates. It was tested on the Drone Propeller Thrust Tester (all results below).

It was printed at a slow speed, using a 0.2 nozzle at 0.04 height per layer. The final part was cleaned using an X-ACTO Knife

After this, I then got to finish the propeller with a 500 grit sandpaper.

These are the thrust readings for the 4 picked voltage values (these can also be viewed in the image files):

  • 1.5V => 18.26 grams
  • 2V => 27.71 grams
  • 2.5V => 36.21 grams
  • 3V => 41.09 grams

The files you'll download contain all pictures relevant to the test, along with 6 txt files that contain airfoil coordinates, the STL files and finally the SLDPRT files. If you want to use the propeller, you need to get a couple of 8520 coreless motors.

You can use the SLDPRT files, in case you desire to make your own changes to the propeller.

P.S. The airfoil plotted by using the matplotlib library for python.

author: a1966551

title: FT-2020 i3 Prusa Filament Runout Sensor

description.text:
This is a mechanical filament sensor for FT-2020 i3 Prusa 3D Printers. It works with most 1.75 mm filaments. I like this end stop set up instead optical sensors which could fail with clear filament color & this is a positive mechanical displacement switch.

You can buy end stop sensor switches & cables from:
https://smile.amazon.com/gp/product/B01FX8SR8A
or..
https://www.biqu.equipment/collections/switch-sensor/products/5pcs-lowest-price-black-mechanical-endstop-without-the-wheel-for-reprap-ramps-1-4-3d-printer-with-independent-packing
or other similar places.... (Most printer kits have 1 or 2 extra, so check your left over parts bin).

Use 2x, M3 x 10 socket head cap screws with nuts on the opposite side to mount the switch. Check the switch with some spare filament. You may need to slightly bend the switch arm out 1 mm to ensure switch is closed when filament is in the guide. Some mechanical adjustments are expected here as switches & part prints vary. Fusion 360 file included in case you want to customize.

Firmware changes in Marlin requires enabling un-commenting the below in the "Configuration.h" file

define FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SENSOR
if ENABLED(FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SENSOR)
define FIL_RUNOUT_INVERTING true // set to true to invert the logic of the sensor.
define ENDSTOPPULLUP_FIL_RUNOUT // Uncomment to use internal pullup for filament runout pins if the sensor is defined.
define FILAMENT_RUNOUT_SCRIPT "M600"
endif

Be sure to set "#define FIL_RUNOUT_INVERTING" to TRUE - by default it is false. The switch shown is normally open configuration. If your setup is NC, this statement would be false. More details can be found in the diagram here:
http://www.smidgeindustriesltd.com/reprap/mech_endstops.png

Also un-comment, and enable servos with this line in the servo section:
define NUM_SERVOS 3

The switch cable will need to be re-pinned per the photos - swapping RED and BLACK wires.

Plug the revised cable into the SERVO3_PIN as shown with RED wire oriented as shown

Note, this switch can also be used with OctoPi - see details noted in this Thingiverse post here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2147179

Printer:

Folger Technologies Prusa i3 2020

Doesn't Matter

No

20% min up to 100%

title: HICTOP Print Bed Wing Nut Clips

description.text:
After having my print bed's adjustment wing nuts turn on their own, be it from me pushing a bit on the bed or for some other reason, I decided to put a stop to it. There will be no more random print bed level adjustments here. :-)

These are rather simple clips that slide over the ends of the bed carriage and prevent the wing nuts from turning. There are two versions of them, which are mirror images of each other, with two of each needed for a print bed.

I've included the STL models for the two types, as well as an STL file that has a set of four that are ready to print.

I'm told that these may be too large for at least one HICTOP model, the 3DP-08. Unfortunately I don't have more information about what part is too large.

They were originally made for my 3DP-17, but if someone with another model (like the 3DP-08) could give me information about where they are too large and by how much, I'll try to adjust them to work for you.

I'd like them to be useful for as many people as possible. :-)

author: alphap

description.text:
Today I decided to change the way how the main controller board is mounted.
By default is just hanging on the frame and waiting to be shorted by the aluminium profile underneath. It is not mounted securely (only one edge of the board, 2 small screws in plastic mountings).
I have used jodbe's design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:193965). It has really smart solution to hold all the wires - it has built in canals so the wires are not sticking out anymore and the unit becomes very flat.
I have just modified it slightly by removing fan'?s mounting points, cutting away side of the board and adding 2 mounting points for my frame clips. Depends on the location on the frame, FULL (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:221362) or FLAT (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:225642) clip may be used. You can find more details on my blog: http://ljwinkler.blogspot.com/2014/01/controller-board-mount-for-velleman.html

A spool-stand (roller) for spools for any axis-diameter.
You need some additional material as there are:
16 M8-Nuts
1 m threaded rod M8 (8 mm)
4 standard ball bearings (best is abec 11) for inline scates

I modified the axis because of some poor grip between spools and axis. The axis is best printed in vertical stand, but sometimes breaks apart from the heatbed because of extruder-vibration. Therefore I applied four struts which stabilizes the work-process in a reliable way (see photo). Just crack them away like normal support.

title: 9/16" UNF cap for Inspiration CCR solenoid LP hose

description.text: A 9/16" male UNF dust cap with a hollow to allow it to fit on a low-pressure regulator hose. Designed as a dust cap for the inspiration vision rebreather solenoid LP hose and BOV LP hose.

If not smooth inside may require gentle sanding. Sharp edges on the inside will damage the sealing o-ring on the low-pressure hose.
On my printer, the inner hollow fits snugly over the o-ring giving a dust seal. It is probably splash proof but not waterproof.
DO NOT PRESSURISE THE HOSE with the cap on.

description.text:
It is really difficult to get at the oil filter of the Hyundai Atos I was servicing. The manual calls for a tool to get thought the tight space from the front when the grill is removed. So I made one!
This socket is designed to connect to a ratchet. An extension will be needed to get at the filter.

Here is the public Onshape file: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/54690c9000ce3a59f5f8974c/w/c5ca347ad67524bb367cb70b/e/9c50751dbb47553c7f618c90

The cross reference for this filter are:
GUD Z223
MANN-F W671
VALEO 586022
BOSCH 0986452061
BOSCH 0986B00023
PUROLATOR L19212
QUINTO... WL7200
According to http://www.autopartoo.com/oem/gud-filters/z223qyn.html

print_settings.Notes:: I sliced these into easy to print pieces for glueing together. The head and both legs have included "supported" files, generated by meshmixer, in addition to the raw file if you want to make your own supports. I recommend printing in PETG or something stronger than PLA since the small arms and toes of the model could easily break off with handling.

title: T. Rex Easy Print and Glue

description.text: I sliced this beautiful model up for easier printing with less support. It printed out wonderfully, but I think that you all could probably do a better job gluing than I did. I printed this with 30% infill except the arms which got 50% for a little extra strength. I used 4 perimeters and top/bottom layers (shells), but 5 in the arms. This model looks great at .1mm layer height but would probably look even better at .05mm.

comments.text: so i printed the version sliced into the most pieces and im trying to figure out how to attach the head. its got a small peg on the back of it and i see the ring piece is what is supposed to hold it to the shaft but its a completely different size.
comments.author: joehouin

comments.text: The ring should fit over the shaft of the arrow and the arrow head peg should fit into the arrow shaft.  If not, cut off the peg and glue it, or drill out the shaft

title: Nerf Cycloneshock cylinder mod, 3 regular + 3 mega darts

description.text:
A cylinder for shooting both mega darts (3) and regular darts (3) with the Nerf Cycloneshock. Regular ones have a lot more power behind it with this mod. The only other alteration is the removal of the air restrictor.
It is a remix of Horsengineer's cylinder, with his the barrels were too short (less accuracy) and too narrow (could be my printer). I always take 5mm margin, his model had about .15mm margin. I also added some fillets. Printed at 0.1mm thickness, 10% infill, 48mm/s 11hours, PETG.

Enjoy!!

description.text:
This is a simple antenna protector that I designed.
The primary objective was to keep it light and very strong.
I designed it for the AOMWAY 4-leaf clover antenna, but should fit all 5.8ghz antennae which are the same style.
There is a lot of people who agree that the video quality of this antenna is the best value for money! and everyone agrees that the antenna in its OEM form does not survive a lot of crashes!

Infill:

20-30% (does not matter)

Notes:

Print 2 identical copies that make the two halves of the antenna cover.

Assembly

The antenna is printed in two halves. I suggest just holding the two halves together and run thin CA along the joint. A small spray of CA accelerator (kicker) is of great help.
Remember, the base should be snug against the semi-rigid coax cable for the antenna.

Additional strengthening (recommended)

Drill a small hole on the top and fill a small amount of moisture curing PU adhesive. This would Expand and fill up the cavity. This enormously increases the strength and durability of the antenna case.

title: RealAcc x210 Pro / V+ Lipo Protector

description.text:
Have your lipo protected ánd a nice stand for your Realacc x210 Pro, just print this model in TPU or other flexible filament. Attach this protector with the two front bolts of the frame. description.text:
This is a clamp for the P3steel 2.x Y-axis.
Designed for use with IGUS RJ4JP-01-08 bearings.

it has round edges so look more smooth.

According to igus you need to put the bearings into a 15 H7 Hole.
You can use a hydraulic pipe 18 x 1,5 and 24 mm long.

When you fit the bearings into the pipe you have the tolerances +0,000 + 0,040.
Put these on a shaft with diameter 8 h6 and you don't have any slackness left.

description.text:
I want to carry an SD Card on my key ring for 3D Printing reasons, so I printed off one of the source Things to do the job. However I could not get over the fact that this design places the card perpendicular to the keys and other items that hang on the ring, and thus this caddy hung at an awkward angle.

So I went about fixing that by redesigning it to sit the card flat against the keys. The only thing that is really the same as the source Thing is the wall section and internal size, but otherwise works the same.

EDIT 1: I've updated the model to be a little more compact, and be a bit less savage on holding the card in.

EDIT 2: I've added an Angled version that hangs a bit nicer on the keyring, and a skeletonised version of said angled one for extra cool points. I've spent way too long on this.

author: ptrilla

description.text:
This is a tiny (70mm / 2.8in tall) miniature of the Nefertiti bust. I've 3D printed it with 100um resolution and carefully post-processed to remove any imperfections. To give it an authentic look, I coated it with two layers of Metallic Silver paint (an acrylic paint with powdered silver). I finished it with clear, very durable wax-based coat (for additional protection from environmental factors, such as UV light, rain, etc.).

This 3D CAD model was originally made available by artists Nikolai Nelles and Nora Al-Badri under Creative Commons License. The uploaded CAD file is reduced to 200k faces resolution to make the file more manageable, while still yielding excellent print quality. The size is kept original, so if you want to print a miniature version, like I did, you can easily scale it down to the desired size in a slicer software of your choice (I used Cura).

If you like it and would like to get a copy of the finished model, you may get it at my etsy store, at https://shiftedparadigmsshop.etsy.com

Let me know if you have any questions.

Happy printing!

description.text: This is a cup handle for the Mossy Oak 30 oz. travel mug. The ID is tapered so it will "lock" onto the OD of the mug. You may need to print and scale it up to get it to the location on the mug you want. I scaled it by 1.5%. My suggestion would be to print a few layers, stop the print and test the fit of the handle on the mug. Scale, and repeat as necessary.

Basic Overwatch Emblem
3 inches in diameter
0.4 inches high
3D model was made from the generic Overwatch emblem by cropping the original image then turning it into a bitmap on Inkscape, then I transfered it into Blender where I made it a solid model and then added the base so that the top piece of the emblem would not fall off. Another possible solution for this is adding a small ring in the inside to connect both pieces.
Tips and/or other feedback is always welcome.
Hope your print comes out great!
Simple Overwatch Print For best results dont print over 200% its original size of 3 inches in diamater

3D printing software that reads STL files.

description.text:
This is a OpenSCAD script to add hair to your existing .STL models. Just edit the script, read the instructions inside the .scad file, import your model, print and become an hairdresser. You also need to know a bit of OpenSCAD, just edit the text file variables, press F6 and export STL. it is actually easy!! come on!! Remember that the .STL for the import command should be centered or you'll have to center yourself in the script with the convenient translate command included in the example, otherwise just delete the translate command or comment it out. A customizer can't be done because you have to provide a local file for the .STL model. So you have to install and run OpenScad to load the script and your models.

I designed this when I saw some inspiring models out there and thought it should be cool to add some hair to your favoirite models. Included are some models, one of a hairy Marvin and a simple hairy tree. Make your own and let us see!! Don't add support at print time as the hair should print over the air.

Two hairized examples provided. My strong Marvin and a simple tree. Included original models for testing. Editing the script you can create a pie cylinder for partial hairizings like the shown in the Marvin model with or without the surrounding wall. Printing without the surrounding wall is convenient when you want the 'dropped hair' effect, this way the hair tends to drop down (in this case the faster you print the more the hair drops due to hotter and softer material).

Enjoy!

description.text:
This is a remix/fusion done in TinkerCAD of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:805803 MPCNC Blank Tool Holder and https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:65939 Greg's Wade extruder for Prusa i3. The blank mount was lengthened to stop the Stepper motor hitting a ball-race on the z-axis and some fillets onto extruder were added for strength. I also slotted the Wade idler screw-holes for quick release. It isn't pretty but for me it does the job. You can edit the object here https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3pOyp0FXSFe Your mileage may vary....
Cheers
Update: Added a proximity sensor bracket , this type LJC18A3-H-Z/BX 1-10mm Capacitance Proximity Sensor Switch NPN NO DC 6-36V 300mA from Amazon. Also fixed the idler part height as it was floating 1mm in air above bed so it wouldn't print , this error appeared to be from the original Wade Extruder file. Enjoy.....

This is a modular cooling system for the MakerFarm Prusa i3. It uses 2 40mm fans (accepts both 40x40x10 and 40x40x20), one to cool the filament as it comes out of the nozzle, and one to cool the fins of the hot end. It was initially designed for a Metal Magma hot end, but it may also work with a J-Head MK-V hot end since it is only a few mm shorter than a Metal Magma. I have also included a modified fan shroud and cooling duct to work with the J-Head MK-IV hot end.

title: Remotely controlled - Arduino Self balancing robot

description.text:
NEW B-robot EVO 2:

Extremely fast, stable and customizable self-balancing robot
The B-robot EVO 2 is an OPEN SOURCE, arduino based self-balancing robot with many features (take a look at the description below)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d6J0ijMG3jI&feature=youtu.be
Now with battle arms and add-ons to fight another robots (or stand up when you fall).

Remotely controlled using your smartphone or tablet (WIFI).

This robot is the natural evolution of the B-robot ORIGINAL and uses the same electronics and motors you would need to create the:
Air Hockey Robot
Sphere-O-Bot (eggbot MOD)
iBoardbot
(and more to come...)
Get tired of one robot? Create another just printing the 3D parts!

B-robot EVO 2 is an Arduino based robot. An Open software and hardware creation. You can easily modify its behaviour changing the acceleration/speed/stability parameters in the Arduino CODE.

questions? improvement ideas? comments? new add-ons? visit the B-robot community!

New features:

  • Control it using your smartphone/tablet via the free jjRobots APP
  • Google Blockly controllable!
  • Perfect to have fun as you learn robotics (Take a look at the Robotics Challenges! )
  • Now can use regular AA batteries (or a 3 cells LIPO battery)
  • Two SERVO outputs (one used for the ARM)
  • Easier to print and using less plastic
  • PRO MODE can be activated from your smartphone/Tablet (increased agility and velocity)
  • Increased WIFI range (up to 40 meters )
  • NEW: (Android devices) control your B-robot using the JJrobots FREE APP!
  • NEW: Create your own bumper with the Thingiverse customizer!
  • NEW: New wheel model for nytrile o-rings [V11]

What you need to print:

· 2x Wheels
. 2x Hub
· Arm
· 2x Side Panel
· Top Shelf
· Motor Shelf
· Electronics Shelf
. 2x Bumpers (to create your customised bumper, follow this link)

ADD-ONS:

· OPTIONAL: 2x Bumper (TOP FRONT Bumper)
. OPTIONAL: Battle arm: Thor hammer
. OPTIONAL: Battle arm: War Axe
. OPTIONAL: Gopro camera support
. OPTIONAL: Soda Can Top shelf support
. OPTIONAL: O-ring Wheels (x2)

HERE

description.header: How does this robot works? How is it capable of keeping the balance? How do I control it? Can I change its behaviour? and modify it?
description.text:
We have created the "Robotic Challenges", perfect to learn robotics, answer robotics questions and have fun at the same time:
Find the perfect compromise between balance and speed to win a race, make the robot follow a set of instructions or bring a beverage can to you not dropping it. How? Take a look at the Challenges! (more coming soon) Find the perfect balance between top speed and manoeuvrability. This challenge aims to get the most of the B-robot EVO 2 while you have fun adjusting its behaviour. Tune the robot for different circuits and race modes! Get to the RACING challenge Make your B-robot bring you a soda can Use the "Top Shelf for CAN" holder 3D part and make the robot bring you a soda can.
The challenge: how fast can the robot make its way to you not dropping the can? Teach it the best way modifiying its balance parameters in real time from your tablet/smartphone. Get to the WAITER challenge Use Google blockly to control your B-robot This challenge aims to show you how to control a robot via sequential commands. Google Blockly is the perfect tool for this: Visual and easy to use. Controlling your robot via Google blockly

comments.text: Can I use an Arduino Uno as the "Brain?"

comments.text: No.The processor the Leonardo uses allows two TIMERs (used to control the stepper motors with accuracy). We needed those two timers to handle interruptions and the Arduino UNO is not capable of doing that. And Arduino Mega can, but it was a little bit too expensive.

remixed_from.author: fortwienix
remixed_from.title: Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus Template for Simplify3D

description.text:
Ultimaker 2 Template for Simplify3D

This is a remix of Mike Bogutsch's (fortwienix) Wanhao Template for S3D, Many thanks for his permission to use his instructions as below.

(The template I have made is for Simplify3D but I have read somewhere that it also works with other slicers.)

At the moment the Template is for the Ultimaker2, UMO and UM3 may follow shortly

Simplify3D template Installation:

Copy the stl file (e.g. UltimakerPrintBed.stl) to the following folder:
C: \ Users \ USERNAME \ AppData \ Local \ Simplify3D \ S3D software
Start Simplify3D and export your FFF profile to the desktop (File-> Export FFF profile)
Open the profile with an editor e.g:Notepad and search for the following entries (about line 145 ish)....
overridePrinterModels>0</overridePrinterModels
printerModelsOverride></printerModelsOverride
.....change the upper value from 0 to 1 and in the second line enter the name of the template. like below

overridePrinterModels>1</overridePrinterModels
printerModelsOverride>TEMPLATE NAME.STL</printerModelsOverride
If overridePrinterModels already is set to 1, you do not need to change this.

Save the FFF profile and import it back to Simpify3D
Restart Simplify3D

Tip:
If you think the template is not centered. Import the model to Simplify3D, change the position and Export the model (File->Export Models->Export Binary STL)

The STL file was produced using.
SolidWorks CAD software, the original model files were from GitHub.

Thanks to Mike for the original Wanhao template, permission to copy and use his original instructions which are clear and easy to follow, and the idea to add the UM2 one.

This is a 'What Duck" design
Just goofing

description.text: I created this S clip to hold the cut end of filament on my 3d spools. It clips over the spool and has inner clip for filament end. Was made for Inland spools but I would imagine it would fit others. I have included the g file along with blend file if you would like to make adjustments. I was using left extruder on print in low quality since quality was not a concern. I also noticed (if you look at the last picture) the filament side of the clip slides into both the left and right inner corner notches. I printed one in each color spool I have. This not only helps to stores the clip when I load a spool, it is an easy indicator which color is loaded on each side without having to look over the back of the printer. :)

title: Spool Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Fusion 360 model: http://a360.co/2qPwKBp

I had the material wire spool directly on a 8mm threaded Rod.
When the feeder pulled the wire or the stepper moved the nozzle, the spool was unwind with a jerky motion due to the offset from the center of the spool.
This was no good for the precision of the print.

I have designed this to clip on each side of the spool and slide on a 8mm rod with no ball bearings (this is smooth enough for me)

This design can be adapted to fit ball bearings,
this design snaps in the 56mm spool hole and any width spools can be used. This design can be adapted for different diameters.
This design can help you mount more spools on the same rod, maintaining a smooth wire delivery.

description.text:
(The hide in the photos has been scaled down in size so if you print the file it'll be slightly bigger)
Just a quick snake hide I whipped up, has a place they can wrap themselves around as well as a place to hide in the dark.
Could be used for small lizards like a baby crested gecko or even bigger ones if you have a big enough print bed and scale it up in your design software or slicer.

After having a problem with mites infesting my baby corn snake I cleared the viv out of aspen shavings and replaced with kitchen roll, this made it look very bare as there was only one hide and no aspen the crawl under. So instead of going out and buying a new hide I decided to quickly whip up a new one.
I would like to make a version II which could have more of a natural look so you could paint it and give it a really professional feeling.
While this should be perfectly safe for your reptile I cannot guarantee and take no responsibility that all plastics are pet safe, please check what you're using as some plastics could give off fumes if a hot enough temperature is reached. I used a PLA and it is fine.

title: Anet A8 - Rear Sensor Mount M18

description.text:
A few reasons to build my own sensor mount :

  • I did not like the sensor mount in the front because you can't see the nozzle very good
  • existing ones for the back uses 2 holders and stability is not very good
  • i want a simple possibility to adjust heigt with only one screw
  • stable, solid and only one piece to print without suppports

My other things for the Anet A8:

  • Case for the PowerPanel-LCD : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2289073
  • Case for the Power-Supply : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2289225
  • Rear Sensor mount : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2306747
  • Front Fan Cover : https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2307700

Please don't forget to post your Makes ...

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50

You have to tap 2 threads of M4 in the existing holes of the bottom holder.
You can do this without dismounting anything. Very easy.

If you use the shipped extruder from your ANET A8 you have to change the following positions in skynet :

#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 21 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]
#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 54 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]
...
#define FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 54
Tinkercad

comments.text:
Hi,
thank you for this nice design. I printed another version with the two holders but the M18 from the sensor was loosen some time later.
I think your design is more stabile.

title: Motorcycle Bar End
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are handlebar ends I made for My Renthal FatBars, but they will work for any bars with threaded ends really. The main bodies are straight forward to print, but there are some other parts involved to finish them off. I had all of this stuff lying around but you may have to source some of it (all available at local Hardware store) as follows.
• 2 - Steel Serrated Flange Locknuts – M6X1.00 – McMaster Carr equivalent : 96595A101
• 2 – S/S Socket Head Screws – M6 X~ 60mm (YMMV) - McMaster Carr equivalent : 91292A413
• 2 inches of Reinforced Fuel line – .5” OD. X.25” ID. - McMaster Carr equivalent : 54605K32
• 2 - 1”OD flat washers. I used some perforated Aluminum ones I had from Bolt Motorcycle hardware (Part #: 2009-AWW.25) I made a model of it that could easily be printed and spray painted if you so choose.
• 4 - ~1”OD rubber O-rings

title: Asterion easy and cheap 3D printed full screw CNC machine

description.text:
!!!PLEASE NOTE!!!
This is WIP... Altough it works perfectly fine it still hasn't completed its first milling operation, just some drawings. Homing couldn't be tested yet either due to a broken Uno.
Altough I see no issue resulting in total failure, this machine is still in its testing phase.
!!!PLEASE NOTE!!!

Asterion is a cheap and easy to build CNC machine featuring lead screws on all axis.

When I decided to build my own CNC machine I knew it had to be cheap which meant that the stepper motors I could afford, would be very weak. Altough there are many belt variants like the MPCNC or Root 2 around, I wasn't able to find a good full screw CNC machine design.
Therefore I designed my own machine based on the Root 2 idea. The only part used from this machine was the linear guide for the 25x25 mm aluminium square tube.

Its total cost without the spindle and the used filament is around 125€.
If you want to rebuild this machine, please refer to the BOM (bill of materials) and assembly instructions in the attached .zip folder.

If you want to use parts of the machine for your project, please refer to the parts description (PD.txt) in the attached .zip folder. You should find the specifications for the most important parts there.

The parts with a larger footprint come in a brim and a brim free version. For printing on machines with warp problemes I can recommend to print the brim design directly on the glass surface.

If you are in need of a fast answer for your question regarding this machine, please contact me via thingiverse or facebook.
https://www.facebook.com/arktarus
